subSections.title: Glyph origin
subSections.text:
Unorthodox variant {{Han simp|茲|nocap=y}} with {{l|zh|䒑}} as the top component instead of {{l|zh|艹}} found in the Ming dynasty orthographic dictionary <big>《俗書刊誤》</big>.

The earliest known form of this character can be traced back to the {{w|Han dynasty}} 《{{w2|zh|孔宙碑}}》 tablet written in {{w|clerical script}}. <!-- Refer http://dict.variants.moe.edu.tw/variants/rbt/word_attribute.rbt?educode=A03473-002#11 -->

This character became the orthodox form in mainland China based on the 1965 Table of General Used Chinese Characters for Publishing 《{{w2|zh|印刷通用漢字字形表}}》 where {{w|Xin Zixing}} ({{w2|zh|新字形#新舊字形對照表|新字形}}) is promulgated for the first time.

subSections.title: Usage notes
subSections.text: * This character, 兹 which contains {{l|zh|䒑}} (3 strokes) is the orthodox form used in mainland China. * The character [[茲#Chinese|茲]] (U+8332) which contains [[艹#Chinese|艹]] (grass radical, 4 strokes in {{w|traditional Chinese}}) is the orthodox form used in modern Taiwan.

subSections.title: References
subSections.text:
* {{R:twedu|A03473#34}} <!-- Pictorial reference for 《俗書刊誤》 -->
* {{R:twedu|A03473-002#11}} <!-- Pictorial reference for 《孔宙碑》 -->

subSections.title: Glyph origin
subSections.text: {{w|Variant Chinese character|Variant form}} of <big>{{l|zh|玆}}</big> with <big>{{l|zh|䒑}}</big> instead of doubled {{l|zh|亠}} as the top component. Found in the Tang dynasty orthographic dictionary {{w|Ganlu Zishu}} 《{{w2|zh|干祿字書}}》, which lists both <big>兹</big> and {{l|zh|茲}} as unorthodox forms of <big>{{l|zh|玆}}</big>. <!-- Note: The printed reference in the Dictionary of Chinese Character Variants has been broken into two portions. The complete statement reads 「茲、兹、玆， 並上俗中通下正。」 , where 玆 the final character is given as the orthodox form (正), while the first two are its variant forms (俗) -->
